An Empirical Evaluation of Visual Question Answering for Novel Objects

Santhosh K. Ramakrishnan1, 2, Ambar Pal1, Gaurav Sharma1, Anurag Mittal2

1IIT Kanpur           2IIT Madras

Published in CVPR 2017 (Poster)

NOTE: We have updated the dataset in the project GitHub repository post acceptance. We will shortly provide a report with updated statistics and results.

Abstract:

We study the problem of answering questions about images in the harder setting, where the test questions and corresponding images contain novel objects, which were not queried about in the training data. Such setting is inevitable in real worldâ€”owing to the heavy tailed distribution of the visual categories, there would be some objects which would not be annotated in the train set. We show that the performance of two popular existing methods drop significantly (up to 28%) when evaluated on novel objects cf. known objects. We propose methods which use large existing external corpora of (i) unlabeled text, i.e. books, and (ii) images tagged with classes, to achieve novel object based visual question answering. We do systematic empirical studies, for both an oracle case where the novel objects are known textually, as well as a fully automatic case without any explicit knowledge of the novel objects, but with the minimal assumption that the novel objects are semantically related to the existing objects in training. The proposed methods for novel object based visual question answering are modular and can potentially be used with many visual question answering architectures. We show consistent improvements with the two popular architectures and give qualitative analysis of the cases where the model does well and of those where it fails to bring improvements.

We are interested in answering questions about images containing objects not seen at training.

Data

Qualitative Results:

Some qualitative results for our proposed model (P) and the baseline (B) are shown along with the ground truth (GT). In the first row, we can observe that P has successfully induced the concepts of necktie, apple, event and flavor into the VQA framework whereas the B has failed to reason based on them. Some of the failure cases of P are illustrated in the second row. It has failed to induce the concepts of restaurant and direction. We also feel that in the last 2 cases, it has predicted purely based on the text modelling. For example, in the fourth case it says that the plane is in motion and in the fifth case it says the ink is red. This could be because it witnessed similar textual examples and the image is not convincing enough for it to say otherwise.

Quantitative Results:

Results are reported on the different question categories for architectures 1 and 2. Feat refers to the image feature used and can be one of VGGNet(VGG), inception(INC), Early Fusion(EF) and Late Fusion(LF) of VGG, INC. Aux refers to the auxilliary data used for pre-training and can be none, text only(text) or weak paired image and text(text+im). Vocab refers to the vocabulary used for encoding the question words and can be one of train only (train), oracle, general (gen) and general expanded from oracle . The baseline model uses oracle / general vocabulary and no auxiliary data. Using text data with the oracle / general vocabulary to pretrain the autoencoder gives consistent improvements over the baseline, especially in the Novel and Yes/No categories. Using weak paired data to pretrain the autoencoders produces marginal improvements over the text only training in some cases, but generally performs worse. This is possibly due to the noisy pairing of text and image data.
